replies.body: ChoGath needs nerfs, but overbuffed Cho is not nearly as game ruining as overbuffed Singed, so I guess Riot prefered to wait and see if people can adapt to new Cho and learn to counter him.

You cant put flash as an argument when enemy ADC also has flash as a summoner spell. His Q is hard to land on any decent player and all other things you mention are literally walking to enemy. Kite. Him. You cant miss CC on him even if you are the worst player in the world. Now if you dont have much CC then its your teams fault for picking the comp. I am not saying that Cho is fine now, his E is broken, but if you get eaten as an ADC you deserve it 150%
Shhh, opposing your adc overlords will only get you downvotes.

Actually flash does have relevance because of two things.

1: Cho can queue his ult so that even if the enemy adc flashes in response, it will have already started (and thus hit them even after flash).

2: Cho can silence, preventing them from flashing.

His R is melee range targeted, this means the animation hasn't even STARTED before he has a valid target, this queuing thing is literal bullshit, lying through your teeth. However, it, like most point-and-click instant abilities doesn't break from the enemy flashing, it's like flashing out of an auto attack.

So yeah, you queue it up and flash into range of the enemy.  They flash quickly in response, but the animation has already started because you set it to cast as soon as you were in range.  You hit them and they blew flash.

What part of my comment was lying?  My point was the ult hits (likely killing them) even if they flash in response.  I never sayed they weren't able to flash during his ult.  It will just hit them regardless of the flash (like an auto attack as you said).
Once Cho is big enough his Q is only hard to hit on champs with decent amounts of MS. Otherwise it's practically free on most anyone.

Actually, you can count flash to a certain extent for the simple reason that the Cho is flashing when they choose to, and the target champion has to flash reactively. Also, instantly repositioning can make predicting his placement for aiming skill shots and CC *slightly* more challenging. Basically an offensive flash has more benefit than a defensive flash because it gives one player greater agency over the situation than the other, by however small a margin it may actually be. The less skilled the two players are, the bigger the advantage to the aggressor, since the target has a greater chance of surviving the faster they can react and analyze the situation.

It is an incredibly small advantage, but it still effects the outcome in Cho's favor.
